headline: What Does It Mean to Tear Down a Statue?
text: Confederate statues and statues of other historical figures, including slave traders and Christopher Columbus, are being toppled throughout the U.S. and around the world this week — an outgrowth of weeks of protests over entrenched racism in the United States, reignited by the killing of George Floyd in police custody.

headline: Reactionaries Are Having a Bad Month
text: What is Braxton Bragg to Donald Trump, or Trump to Braxton Bragg?

headline: Georgia Havoc Raises New Doubts on Pricey Voting Machines
text: As Georgia elections officials prepared to roll out an over $100 million high-tech voting system last year, good-government groups, a federal judge and election-security experts warned of its perils. The new system, they argued, was too convoluted, too expensive, too big — and was still insecure.

headline: Former D.E.A. Spokesman Pleads Guilty to $4.4 Million Fraud
text: A former Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges of defrauding companies of more than $4 million by pretending to be a Central Intelligence Agency officer involved in an intelligence gathering operation, prosecutors said.

headline: Coronavirus Can Set Off a ‘Cytokine Storm.’ These Drugs May Calm It.
text: Many coronavirus patients seem to get better at first, then rapidly decline and are overtaken by an overwhelming immune response that causes the body to turn on itself.

headline: Lebanon’s Currency Plunges, and Protesters Surge Into Streets
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A new wave of anti-government protests erupted across Lebanon on Thursday with people blocking roads, burning tires and chanting against the political elite amid a deepening economic crisis.

headline: Ritchie Torres for Congress in the Bronx
text: All Americans deserve fearless, dogged representation in Washington. But representing the country’s poorest district requires exceptional determination and commitment.

headline: She Witnessed the Pandemic’s Toll From Inside a Funeral Home
text: — Stephanie Garcia, a mortician, on being unable to meet demand

headline: Investors, No Longer in Denial About Grim Outlook, Drive Market Down
text: At least for a day, reality triumphed over hope on Wall Street.

headline: Varner Leads as Golf Makes Its Return in Pin-Drop Silence
text: FORT WORTH — For many of the pro golfers who have not competed in a tournament in 90 days, the first round of the Charles Schwab Challenge was all about shaking off cobwebs from the PGA Tour’s hiatus. But for Harold Varner III, who finished the day in a two-way tie for the lead at seven under par, Thursday’s return was a respite of a different sort.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: As the world anxiously awaits a vaccine, doctors and researchers are making headway on potential treatments for Covid-19 and the damage it causes to the body.

text: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Turkey Court Sentences U.S. Consulate Employee to Over 8 Years in Prison
text: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul court sentenced on Thursday a U.S. Consulate employee to more than eight years in prison on charges of aiding an armed terror group, a ruling likely to exacerbate a long-running dispute between Turkey and the United States over the prosecutions of three Turkish citizens employed by the American government.

headline: Ambush Suspect Is Killed After Wounding 3 Officers in a Standoff, Sheriff Says
text: A man who ambushed a sheriff’s deputy on Wednesday in Paso Robles, Calif., was killed on Thursday after a two-hour standoff during which three law enforcement officers were wounded when they surrounded him in a vineyard, the authorities said.

headline: Moving Beyond ‘MAGA’?
text: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Trump Defends Police, but Says He’ll Sign Order Encouraging Better Practices
text: President Trump offered only a vague policy response on Thursday to the killing of George Floyd, saying he would sign an executive order encouraging better practices by police departments while rejecting more far-reaching proposals to tackle racial injustice and police brutality in the United States.

headline: Trump Cites ‘Bad Apples’ but Defends Nation’s Police
text: President Trump said more resources should be devoted to training but added of police departments, “If they’re allowed to do their job, they’ll do a great job.”

headline: Trump Will Give Convention Speech in Jacksonville, Capping a Dispute Over Safety
text: [Update: Trump abruptly cancels Republican Convention in Jacksonville.]

headline: As Public Opinion Shifts on Racism, Trump Digs In
text: WASHINGTON — NASCAR is demanding that its fans no longer fly Confederate flags at races. The Pentagon and some Republican senators are open to renaming military bases that bear the names of Confederate soldiers. Corporate America is taking stances against racial injustice. A majority of Americans say the police show racial bias in their use of force, and a majority of self-described conservatives acknowledge protesters’ frustrations are at least somewhat justified.

headline: North Korea Vows to Boost Nuclear Program, Saying U.S. Diplomacy Failed
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Friday said that two years of diplomacy with President Trump had “faded away into a dark nightmare,” and vowed to increase its nuclear weapons capabilities.

headline: Trump Supporters Must Waive Right to Sue Over Virus to Attend Rally
text: As part of President Trump’s push for America to return to life as it was before the coronavirus pandemic, he is resuming indoor campaign rallies this month even while health officials continue to say people should avoid crowded places.

headline: Can Anna Wintour Survive the Social Justice Movement?
text: On Monday, as swiftly as a 9-iron taken to a tee at Augusta, Adam Rapoport resigned as the editor in chief of Bon Appétit magazine after a damning Halloween photo circulated on social media that morning. Drawn from the vast insensitivity archives to which so many influential people have made inadvertent submissions, the picture, from 2004, shows him costumed in a tank top and thick chain necklace as his wife’s “papi,’’ the term she attached to it in an Instagram post several years later.

headline: Trump’s Grotesque Tulsa Trip
text: Most people — or, at any rate, most readers of The New York Times — remember Donald Trump’s response to the white nationalist riot in Charlottesville, Va., as a particularly low point in a presidency full of them. After a rambling, aggrieved news conference in which he defended some of those marching with neo-Nazis as “very fine people,” Trump’s already dismal approval rating hovered below 38 percent. Staffers voiced shame and disgust to journalists (anonymously, of course). Senator Susan Collins was “concerned.”

headline: These Are the 10 U.S. Army Installations Named for Confederates
text: Scattered across the American South, 10 Army bases bear the names of Confederate officers, including several who resigned their commissions in the United States military and fought against the Union Army in some of the bloodiest battles of the Civil War.

headline: Jet Setting
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Delicious! This grid is like butter, baby; the cultured, French kind that’s rich enough to make you feel rich, too. This grid is also smart enough to make you feel smart. Hopefully, this grid is fun enough to make your whole weekend fun.

headline: Audrey Gelman, the Wing’s Co-Founder, Resigns
text: Civil rights movements were good for Audrey Gelman, a founder of the upscale women-only club and co-working space the Wing, until they weren’t.

headline: Corrections: June 12, 2020
text: An article on Thursday about a retired federal judge who called the Justice Department’s reversal of the case against Michael T. Flynn a “gross abuse of prosecutorial power” misstated when conversations between Michael Flynn and Sergei Kislyak took place. The men spoke in December 2016, a year before Mr. Flynn first pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about those conversations, not a month before his guilty plea.

headline: George Floyd Protests Inspire Fresh Scrutiny of Policing in Europe, Too
text: PARIS — The killing of George Floyd has resonated in Europe, drawing thousands of demonstrators into the streets of cities like Paris, London and Berlin. Statues of colonizers and slave traders have been pulled down or defaced.

headline: Together.
text: It doesn’t take a Modern Love column to tell you that relationships can flourish — or wither — in times of stress. Add months of isolation, the physical and emotional toll of a pandemic, followed by global protests, and this period we’re living through has the capacity to reshape relationships on a broad scale.

headline: ‘Corona Cycleways’ Become the New Post-Confinement Commute
text: PARIS — As France eased one of Europe’s toughest coronavirus lockdowns last month, a small army of street workers fanned out across Paris in the dark of night. They dropped traffic barriers along car lanes and painted yellow bicycle symbols onto the asphalt. By morning, miles of pop-up “corona cycleways” had been laid, teeming with people heading back to work.

headline: ‘Gulabo Sitabo’ Review: This Old House, Lucknow Style
text: Mirza, the landlord of Fatima Mahal, the picturesquely crumbling mansion at the center of the Hindi film “Gulabo Sitabo” (streaming on Amazon Prime), is fighting a long, cranky war with the tenants he regards as vermin in his house. He steals their light bulbs, cuts their power and locks them out of spare bathrooms when the communal latrine becomes unusable. A swift kick of frustration was all it took to make a person-size hole in its wall.

headline: Global Markets, North Korea, Jaguars: Your Friday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: Zoom Briefly Blocks Activist After Event to Honor Tiananmen
text: “We can’t stand that an American company put Chinese-style restrictions on users in the U.S.”

headline: Wall Street Shakes Off Grim Economic News
text: This briefing is no longer updating. The latest developments can be found here.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Da 5 Bloods’ and ‘Artemis Fowl’
text: DA 5 BLOODS (2020) Stream on Netflix. A group of Vietnam War veterans search for the bones of a fallen comrade and a box full of gold in “Da 5 Bloods,” the latest film from Spike Lee. Anchored in the present day with flashbacks to the past, the movie follows four aging former members of an Army squad — played by Delroy Lindo, Isiah Whitlock Jr., Norm Lewis and Clarke Peters — who return to Vietnam. They’re hoping to dig up the remains of their leader (Chadwick Boseman), who died during the war, and a box of gold bars that the squad had commandeered from the U.S. government, then lost. “This long, anguished, funny, violent excursion into a hidden chamber of the nation’s heart of darkness isn’t like anything else, ” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, “even if it may put you in mind of a lot of other things.”

headline: A Statue Was Toppled. Can We Finally Talk About the British Empire?
text: BRIGHTON, England — Tens of thousands of people protested in British cities in solidarity with those rising up against police brutality against black Americans in the past week. They highlighted similar injustices in Britain. Protesters in the city of Bristol drew connections between a white police officer’s killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis, and the histories of colonialism and the slave trade. On Sunday, they toppled the statue of Edward Colston, a 17th-century slave trader, trampled over it and rolled it into Bristol Harbor.

headline: Korean Adoptee Wins Landmark Case in Search for Birth Parents
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A court in Seoul ruled Friday that a woman adopted by an American couple almost four decades ago must be recognized as a daughter of an 85-year-old South Korean man, providing hope for the thousands of Korean-born adoptees who want to know the identities of their birth parents.

headline: A Return to Dining and Restaurants in Australia
text: The clink of glasses, the whir of an espresso machine, the laughter of other patrons, the banter of a pub owner — I can’t tell you how much I’ve missed these things. The ability to forgo the midafternoon conversation with my husband: What should we make for dinner? No dishes to do!

headline: Jimmy Fallon Asks Trump to Reconsider His ‘Cough-a-palooza’ Rally
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

text: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Cities Grew Safer. Police Budgets Kept Growing.
text: Protesters who are now calling to defund or reform the police are fundamentally questioning what these numbers have become.

headline: What’s Happening While You Are Sleeping? Some Pretty Weird Dreams
text: We asked readers to share what goes through their minds at night.

headline: A Street Wear Designer Who Graduated From ‘Yeezy University’
text: Name: Philip Post

headline: After Virtual Graduation, Protesting for Their Lives
text: Daavion Lee sported a Kelly green cap and gown, and his cousin Daniyah Bennett wore the black regalia from her middle school. They stood in the back of a pickup truck with an organizer of a march against police brutality and racism.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Pandemic Century’ and ‘Dad’s Maybe Book’
text: THE PANDEMIC CENTURY: One Hundred Years of Panic, Hysteria, and Hubris, by Mark Honigsbaum. (Norton, 512 pp., $17.95.) Some scenes in this “deeply researched” history, citing similarities in the world’s response to nine so-called pandemics, are “so vivid” they had our reviewer, Carl Zimmer, “drafting movie treatments” in his head. The paperback edition includes a new chapter on the coronavirus.

headline: How a Virus Triage Tent Became a Serene Oasis for Health Care Workers
text: On a rare quiet evening in late May, Dr. Dahlia Rizk asked her staff to join her by a campfire. They sat together for more than an hour, sharing the overwhelming horrors and occasional triumphs they’d experienced while treating the coronavirus, as the sounds of burning logs crackled in the background and a bright orange glow filled the room.

headline: A Sleepwalker and an Insomniac Walk Into a Bed
text: When we bring our daughter Oona home she won’t sleep for a few days.

headline: Bret Stephens: What The Times Got Wrong
text: Acting editorial page editor Kathleen Kingsbury wrote about the decision to publish our writers’ responses to the Tom Cotton Op-Ed in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: Two D.J.s Trade in Their Turn Tables for More Time Outdoors
text: Hannah Bronfman and her husband, Brendan Fallis, both New York-based event D.J.s, have watched most of their live gigs dry up because of the coronavirus outbreak. But they’re still keeping busy.

headline: For Online Learning, Business Has Never Been Better
text: Around the world, students are learning from home. For Chegg, the online learning company, that has meant unprecedented demand for its services.

headline: Ross Douthat: The Tom Cotton Op-Ed and the Cultural Revolution
text: Acting editorial page editor Kathleen Kingsbury wrote about the decision to publish our writers’ responses to the Tom Cotton Op-Ed in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: A Date to Remember
text: Everything was telling Sam Thirlwall not to take this job. Joining Zapproved, a legal services technology company in Portland, Ore., would mean a pay cut. It also would mean being a manager responsible for a large team, rather than doing what he had done for years, which was building cybersecurity software. Mr. Thirlwall, 36, didn’t know much about the company or legal technology. Even the interview process seemed weird.

headline: To Overturn Trump, We Need to Overturn White Supremacy
text: It doesn’t necessarily follow that a nationwide protest over police brutality would, for some, become a reason to take action against Confederate statues and other controversial monuments. But it has. In just the last week, protesters have knocked down Confederate statues in Richmond, Va., Nashville and Montgomery, Ala., as well as monuments to Christopher Columbus in Boston and St. Paul, Minn.

headline: How 132 Epidemiologists Are Deciding When to Send Their Children to School
text: For many parents, the most pressing question as the nation emerges from pandemic lockdown is when they can send their children to school, camp or child care.

headline: Bob Dylan Has a Lot on His Mind
text: A few years ago, sitting beneath shade trees in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., I had a two-hour discussion with Bob Dylan that touched on Malcolm X, the French Revolution, Franklin Roosevelt and World War II. At one juncture, he asked me what I knew about the Sand Creek Massacre of 1864. When I answered, “Not enough,” he got up from his folding chair, climbed into his tour bus, and came back five minutes later with photocopies describing how U.S. troops had butchered hundreds of peaceful Cheyenne and Arapahoe in southeastern Colorado.

headline: Hair Salons Reopen, and Americans Rush Back
text: Few professional encounters require prolonged bouts of close contact like appointments at hair or beauty salons. This makes beauty, nail and barbershops potentially high-risk hubs of infection for the coronavirus, which has killed almost half a million people worldwide since the start of this year.

headline: Do Police Officers Make Schools Safer or More Dangerous?
text: The national reckoning over police violence has spread to schools, with several districts choosing in recent days to sever their relationships with local police departments out of concern that the officers patrolling their hallways represent more of a threat than a form of protection.

headline: Trump Administration Moves to Solidify Restrictive Immigration Policies
text: WASHINGTON — Under the cloak of a pandemic and the convulsions of anti-racist protests, the Trump administration continues to advance its policies to restrict legal immigration, halting the flow of foreign workers and raising the bar for asylum seekers hoping for sanctuary.

headline: College Athletes, Phones in Hand, Force Shift in Protest Movement
text: They knelt on campuses and outside courthouses and a capitol. They filmed videos and challenged coaches and gripped megaphones to call out racism they knew from their classrooms and stadiums. They led protest chants, registered voters and started to strategize for Nov. 3, Election Day.

headline: Leading the Van Gogh Museum Through a Future With No Tourists
text: AMSTERDAM — Surrounded by sunflowers, Emilie Gordenker stood on a yellow carpet rolled out in front of the Van Gogh Museum. On June 1, the institution’s new director was there to welcome the first visitors back after the coronavirus lockdown. About a dozen were lining up in the sunshine, six feet apart.

headline: After the Pandemic, a Global Hunger Crisis
text: ROME — The coronavirus pandemic and its punitive economic effects are about to set off the next global hunger crisis.

headline: For George Floyd’s Mourners, What Does ‘Justice’ Mean?
text: HOUSTON — Hundreds of American flags lined the street outside George Floyd’s funeral services, as if the deceased were a member of law enforcement, not a black man killed in its custody.

headline: On the Future, Americans Can Agree: It Doesn’t Look Good
text: Brendan Hermanson, 51, a construction worker for three decades, has come through the pandemic healthy and employed. At home in Milwaukee, where he lives with his grown son, he tries to tune out the hostile politics in the country and wonders if he should bother to vote again for President Trump in November or “sit back and watch it crumble.”

headline: How Do We Wrap Our Heads Around Something This Big?
text: On listening to oneself in a world of crisis.

headline: Building on Free or Inherited Land
text: Free land programs have been part of America’s DNA for centuries.

headline: Living on Free Land
text: Many families with the wherewithal to leave dense cities during the pandemic have headed to country homes to shelter in a bigger space. But a handful of families are in a position to do this to an even greater extreme, settling into remote places that they or their ancestors received through free land programs.

text: This was not the wedding that Alyssa Bello and Christian Messina had imagined.

text: In 1979, in a middle school homeroom in Detroit, Wendy Hopkins sat next to Anthony Forbers and developed a crush.

headline: A Shooting Star, and Then Sparks Flew
text: Genevieve Elise Becker and Charles Parker McCarty met through a mutual friend when they were Washington interns in 2014 for two North Carolina senators — she for Kay R. Hagan, a Democrat, and he for Richard M. Burr, a Republican.

headline: A Good Story to Tell Their Future Children
text: When Katherine Hernandez and Jason Perez were each asked to describe their 10-year relationship in a single word, they simultaneously blurted out the same word: amazing.

headline: Kamala Harris, Front-runner (Again)
text: Kamala Harris is emerging as the front-runner to be Joe Biden’s running mate for one reason above all others: She is the only female African-American possibility who has the political experience typical of vice presidents.

headline: Stocks Go Down, Too
text: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Both Candidates Are Widely Disliked (Again). This Time, Biden Could Benefit.
text: It’s a truism of politics: When you’ve got an incumbent on the ballot, the race will be a referendum on her or his leadership — probably more than it’ll be about what the challenger is offering. So with President Trump’s approval rating stuck deep in the red, there’s little doubt that he is facing an uphill battle.

headline: An 8-Year-Old Boy Tried to Pay With Toy Money. It’s Now on a Swiss Police File.
text: PARIS — When an 8-year-old boy walked into a village supermarket in northern Switzerland last month and tried to pay with a fake €50 bill, it seemed like mere childhood mischief.

headline: Neither Big Nor Small, Music Ensembles Struggle in a Pandemic
text: When concert halls began shuttering in March, classical musicians were hit hard and quick. Huge opera companies furloughed orchestras and choruses; tiny groups like string quartets were threatened with collapse.

headline: The Moomins Meet a Real-Estate Developer, and Outrage Ensues
text: Tove Jansson’s Moomins might be Finland’s most famous exports. The author and illustrator is a cherished national icon and, for Finnish readers, her enchanting, snout-nosed characters offer not just an escape into a magical world, but a vision of a Nordic good life in which every creature counts.

headline: Fox News Host Tucker Carlson Loses More Advertisers
text: On Monday’s segment of his prime-time show, the Fox News host Tucker Carlson cast doubt on the reasons behind the worldwide unrest prompted by the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last month.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 1: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Update: Winners have been announced!

text: Good morning.

headline: Arab Envoy Warns Israelis That Annexation Threatens Warming Ties
text: JERUSALEM — In a watershed article in a leading Israeli newspaper, a top diplomat from the United Arab Emirates warned the Israeli public on Friday that unilateral annexation of West Bank territory would endanger Israel’s warming ties with Arab countries.

headline: Pandemic Shopping for Your Neighbors
text: About two weeks ago, I found packets of yeast for sale at a corner market, displayed on a shelf like it was no big deal, like yeast hadn’t become a precious commodity during the coronavirus pandemic as supermarket shelves emptied and Americans took up bread-baking like a national pastime.

headline: Wealth Advisers Torn Over Taking Small-Business Aid
text: The federal government’s multibillion-dollar aid program to help small businesses hurt by the pandemic prompted outrage after billions went to public companies while mom-and-pop businesses were sidelined.

headline: Should Funeral Homes Be Required to Post Prices Online?
text: The coronavirus pandemic may help push the funeral business into the internet age.

headline: For Racial Justice, Employees Need Paid Hours Off for Voting
text: The George Floyd protests have garnered an impressive amount of support, not just from individuals but from a wide range of companies.

headline: An Early Audible for Colleges Starting New Football Teams
text: The posters promoting the inaugural football game at Madonna University started going up around its Livonia, Mich., campus last October, and Josh DePaulis grabbed the first one he saw. He hung it on his bedroom wall, and every morning since, he has woken up, stared at it and said to himself two words: It’s coming.

headline: PG&E Gives Wildfire Victims More Stock in Bankruptcy Plan
text: Pacific Gas & Electric, the California utility that is hoping to resolve its bankruptcy filing in the coming weeks, said on Friday that it had agreed to give victims of wildfires caused by its equipment more stock in the company than an earlier agreement had called for.

headline: First Black ‘Bachelor,’ Matt James, Cast by ABC
text: For the first time, the reality television show “The Bachelor” will have a black lead.

headline: Judge Is Assigned to Officers’ Murder Trial
text: This briefing has ended. Follow our live coverage of Black Lives Matters protests here.

headline: The N.F.L. Embraces Progressive Action, but Not Yet Kaepernick
text: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, the N.F.L., a league that has wrestled with racial issues for years, has shown unusual unity. Players, coaches, league officials and owners have expressed sadness, remorse and a commitment to seek solutions to police violence against African-American people and other forms of social injustice.

headline: Trump’s Actions Rattle the Military World: ‘I Can’t Support the Man’
text: Erin Fangmann grew up in a military family, has been married to a captain in the Air Force for 18 years and has voted Republican all her life, including for Donald J. Trump. But as with a number of other veterans, troops and military family members who have watched the president with alarm, her support has evaporated.

headline: Risking Their Lives in Canada’s Pandemic and Hoping That’s Enough to Stay
text: MONTREAL — Sterly Lucien, a Haitian orderly in a Quebec nursing home, has had sleepless nights for two years, fearful that she and her young son could be deported at anytime. But the 30-year old may find reprieve from an unlikely source: the deadly coronavirus.

headline: There’s No Reason for an Architect to Design a Death Chamber
text: Like many organizations in the wake of George Floyd’s killing, the board of the American Institute of Architects issued a statement the other day expressing solidarity with protesters — and offering a mea culpa. “We were wrong not to address and work to correct the built world’s role in perpetuating systemic racial injustice,” the statement said. But “we support and are committed to efforts to ensure that our profession is part of the solution.”

headline: A Grand History of Small Operas
text: Opera is often assumed to be just about bigness. Powerful voices, huge choruses and imposing orchestral forces dominate our sense of the art form.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Red Oaks’
text: Within a few years after Richard Linklater’s “Dazed and Confused” tanked in theaters in 1993, cheap VHS copies were a staple of dorm rooms and off-campus housing, like shakily constructed loft beds and cereal for dinner. During that period, I was wrapping up my senior year and entering a blurry, two-year townie purgatory in Athens, Ga., before graduate school, which made me the target audience for this particular cult phenomenon. I’ve seen “Dazed and Confused” several times, but in a way I’ve seen it dozens of times because those VCRs were whirring nonstop, on the periphery of parties or other after-hours shenanigans.

headline: Behind the Cover: Tech & Design
text: For this issue, a look at what it will take for scientists to find a treatment and vaccine for Covid-19.

headline: Crunchy, Creamy and Just Sweet Enough
text: Although their name suggests that they’re defined by sweetness, sugar snap peas are really about the crunch.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. Samin Nosrat has a great column this week in The Times, about trying to recreate her favorite kimchi pancake (above), the one she’s been eating at Pyeong Chang Tofu House in Oakland, Calif., for the past 20 years. She got the recipe from Young S. Kim, the restaurant’s owner and chef, then made it for neighbors with store-bought kimchi, who loved the result. Still, it didn’t taste right to Samin until she made it with some of the 1,400 pounds of kimchi that Mrs. Kim makes each month for the restaurant.

headline: Video of Arrest of Indigenous Leader Shocks Canada
text: TORONTO — The police dash cam video shows the Indigenous chief being held by one police officer and tackled to the ground by another, punched in the head and put in a chokehold.

headline: New Breonna Taylor Law Will Ban No-Knock Warrants in Louisville, Ky.
text: Mayor Greg Fischer of Louisville, Ky., said that he would sign “Breonna’s Law” after city council members voted unanimously on Thursday evening to ban “no-knock” warrants, a controversial procedure that the city’s police force used during the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor in March.

headline: Cartoonists Tackle the Big Stuff: O.C.D., Motherhood and Too Many Books

headline: ‘We Fascinated Them’: Shailah Edmonds on a Golden Era of Black Models
text: At a piano bar in the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood of Manhattan, just before night life shut down across the city, a 71-year-old former model named Shailah Edmonds performed her one-woman cabaret show to a two-drink-minimum crowd.

headline: In Fine Print, Airlines Make It Harder to Fight for Passenger Rights
text: As air travel reopens and flight bookings begin to creep up, AvGeeks — aviation geeks — and others may notice some new legalese in the fine print when they buy plane tickets.

headline: Carol Krieger, Who Taught Emotionally Impaired Children, Dies at 80
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Work Diary of Gray Malin, Locked-Down ‘Getaway’ Photographer
text: The pristine aquamarine of a Hawaiian beach, shot from above to capture a smattering of bright umbrellas on the shore. Positano on a hazy summer’s day. Striped sun loungers in St. Tropez.

headline: The Oscars Will Add a Diversity Requirement for Eligibility
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which oversees the Academy Awards, announced Friday a handful of efforts to improve inclusion both within its organization and for the Oscars themselves.

headline: Businesses Want Virus Legal Protection. Workers Are Worried.
text: WASHINGTON — When Jonathan Corpina, a senior managing partner at Meridian Equity Partners, returned to work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in late May, he was met with temperature screenings, hand sanitizer stations, plexiglass barriers — and a liability waiver.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
text: Welcome to the weekend. Uncertainty is hard. Sitting still in what we know is so much easier. But we are not sitting still — not anymore. We’ve gone straight from lockdown and isolation to gathering in the streets. It’s a head-spinning turn. Maybe the weekend is a time to take stock. Whatever you are doing, make time for some amazing journalism.

headline: ‘This Is Not the Flu’: What Doctors Say About Their Fight Against Coronavirus
text: Since March, 40 physicians have created a record of a pandemic in which "grief was the overwhelming theme."

headline: Amazon, Pushing Fashion, Opened Photo Studio as a ‘Warehouse’ Exemption
text: A large Amazon fashion photo studio in Brooklyn, where models pose in clothing sold on the company’s site, sat shuttered for more than two months as the coronavirus spread in New York.

headline: Lil Baby Takes a Stand, and 10 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Delroy Lindo on ‘Da 5 Bloods’ and Playing a Trump Supporter
text: In Spike Lee’s newest film, “Da 5 Bloods” (streaming on Netflix), three African-American veterans of the Vietnam War are dismayed to learn that a fourth buddy, Paul, is now a supporter of President Trump. Delroy Lindo, the actor who plays their conservative pal, said he too was dismayed by the character’s choice.

headline: Liam Gallagher Gets His ‘MTV Unplugged’ Moment
text: Until very recently, to the average Oasis fan, the words “Liam Gallagher” and “MTV Unplugged” brought to mind one of the more infamous — and bleakly hilarious — episodes in the band’s storied existence.

headline: 5 Ways to Be More Politically Involved
text: Protesting is effective, but your voice can be heard in many other ways. Here’s how to get started.

headline: ‘The King of Staten Island’ | Anatomy of a Scene
text: Judd Apatow narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Pete Davidson and Maude Apatow.

headline: How ‘The King of Staten Island’ Handles Sibling Rivalry
text: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: The Latest Police Tool in Protests: Paintball Guns
text: Amid tear gas, rubber bullets and stun grenades, police are turning to a lesser-known crowd control agent: paintballs.

headline: The Italian Cafe Where New Yorkers Sample La Dolce Vita
text: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Your 2020 Virtual Pride Guide

Flynn, as all three judges asked skeptical questions about a request that they intervene and order the case dismissed.

text: On Netflix, a steamy high school romance with strong suggestions of “Gossip Girl.” On Cinemax, a steamy international thriller with harried spies and a strong, silent hero.

headline: Fed Warns of ‘Extraordinarily Uncertain’ Path to Recovery
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve painted a sober picture of the economy on Friday, declaring that the financial system remains under stress because of the coronavirus pandemic and that the path back to steady growth and a strong labor market is unsure.

headline: One Big Difference About George Floyd Protests: Many White Faces

headline: Target, Don’t Tell Me You ‘Stand With Black Families’
text: UNION, N.J. — Last week, the Target Corporation sent out an email about its commitment to “social justice.” “We stand with black families,” it said. A year and half ago, when a police officer intervened after an incident involving my disabled African-American son in a Target store, our family didn’t even get an apology.

headline: Crushing: A Schoolgirl’s Beloved Teacher Crosses the Line
text: There’s a grim familiarity to stories about young girls falling prey to men in positions of power. As readers, we recognize the girl’s first heady thrill at being called special by someone who seems to have the authority above all others to declare it, and then we follow that plotline to its heart-rending conclusion. The best-selling authors Candace Bushnell and Katie Cotugno explore this territory in RULES FOR BEING A GIRL (Balzer + Bray, 304 pp., $19.99; ages 13 and up), a book so engaging and lively it might take you a moment to pinpoint the disquiet you feel upon reaching its end.

headline: Amid a Pandemic, ‘Batman’ Matters More Than Ever
text: SINGAPORE — The bat is considered lucky in China; the words for bat and good fortune sound alike in Chinese. But Wang Linfa didn’t give much thought to the order Chiroptera while growing up in Shanghai in the 1960s and ’70s, when the main sign of nighttime life was the soft whir of commuters bicycling home from factories.

headline: Playing the Paper
text: People around the globe shell out billions of dollars each year on professionally manufactured games: According to a recent study, spending worldwide on playing cards and board games is expected to reach nearly $22 billion by the year 2025. But the truth is that you can turn anything into a game — even a newspaper! These fun hexagon tiles are flexible game components that allow for a variety of games and play styles. You can make your own by cutting up a newspaper and folding it using the instructions below.

headline: How French Soccer Fell Apart
text: PARIS — Finally, it seemed, the battle was over. After a month of uncertainty and infighting and turmoil, French soccer at last had closure. The highest administrative court in the country, the Conseil d’État, had made its ruling: The soccer season was finished.

headline: Vicki Wood, Who Broke Car-Racing Gender Barriers, Dies at 101
text: She was called “the fastest woman in racing” and “the fastest woman on the sand.” Her explosive speed on the hard-packed sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., in 1960, topping 150 miles per hour, earned her a place in the record books.

headline: Honda Hackers May Have Used Tools Favored by Countries

headline: ‘We Want to See Action’: Why Black Supporters Are Deserting de Blasio

headline: As Money Squabbles Delay M.L.B., Many Workers ‘Just Get Steam-Rolled’
text: Like thousands of minor league baseball players, Zack Kelly knew May 31 was an important date. With professional baseball on pause because of the pandemic, M.L.B. had ensured minor leaguers would be paid $400 a week through the end of the month — and Kelly had a hunch that some players would be released as that expiration date approached.

headline: Low on Chocolate Chips? These Cookies Love a Substitution
text: Has everyone’s surreptitious chocolate chip consumption gone way up since we’ve all had to stay at home? Or is this phenomenon limited to my particular kitchen? And is it also why, no matter how often I replenish the stock, there’s never quite enough left in the bag whenever I try to bake cookies?

headline: Blackface on British TV Finally Faces a Reckoning
text: LONDON — On Thursday night, the British chat-show host Trisha Goddard discussed the impact of an impersonation of her by a white comedian in blackface that was popular on television here in the early 2000s.

headline: Tulsa Police Investigate Officer After Remarks About Race and Shootings
text: The Police Department in Tulsa, Okla., said it was investigating one of its officers over remarks he made in a radio interview this week in which he spoke about police shootings of black Americans, amid nationwide protests against racism and ahead of President Trump’s visit next week.

headline: Trudeau Calls for Transparent Investigation of Indigenous Leader’s Arrest
text: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada called the video showing police officers arresting Chief Allan Adam of Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation “shocking.”

headline: A Tennessee Man Called Police for Help, Then Died in Their Custody
text: Sterling Higgins called the police in March 2019 and told them someone was following him and trying to kill him. When officers arrived at a convenience store parking lot in northwestern Tennessee, they found Mr. Higgins distressed and yelling at a woman whom he accused of stealing from him.

headline: Harry Potter Fans Reimagine Their World Without Its Creator
text: When J.K. Rowling was accused of transphobia about two years ago for “liking” a tweet that referred to transgender women as “men in dresses,” much of the Harry Potter fandom tried to give their beloved author the benefit of the doubt. Perhaps it really was just an accident, a “clumsy and middle-aged moment,” as Ms. Rowling’s spokesperson said at the time.

headline: French Police Push Back Against Proposed Reforms
text: PARIS — The French police, furious at a popular backlash against them in the wake of the George Floyd killing, have pushed back against government attempts to change their practices and discipline officers suspected of racism, demonstrating Friday in Paris and throwing down handcuffs in front of police stations all over France.

headline: Starbucks Will Allow Employees to Wear Black Lives Matter Apparel
text: Starbucks said on Friday that employees would be allowed to wear Black Lives Matter shirts and pins, a sudden reversal of a company policy that had banned the phrase because it could “amplify divisiveness.”

headline: Putin Wants Parades Ahead of Key Vote. Local Officials Aren’t So Sure.

headline: Oleh Hornykiewicz, Who Discovered Parkinson’s Treatment, Dies at 93
text: Oleh Hornykiewicz, a pharmacologist whose breakthrough research on Parkinson’s disease has spared millions of patients the tremors and other physical impairments it can cause, died on May 26 in Vienna. He was 93.

headline: C.D.C. Calls for Masks at Large Gatherings, Warning of Crowd Risks
text: Three months after the country’s top public health agency, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, abruptly stopped holding regular briefings on the coronavirus pandemic, its director, Dr. Robert Redfield, restarted them on Friday amid growing calls for the agency to claim a more prominent role in the virus response.

headline: Virus Delays Passports for 1.7 Million Americans
text: WASHINGTON — Sarah Farris, an American living in Singapore, rushed to her parents’ home in Florida in April to see her father before he died. She is now stuck, unable to return to her job, because she has been unable to renew her expiring passport.

headline: How Much Longer Will the Border Stay Shut?
text: This week Prime Minister Justin Trudeau may have resolved some of the concerns Canada Letter readers have raised in emails about the border closing with the United States. A tweak to its rules now means that married and common law couples who had found themselves unable to reunite if they weren’t both Canadian citizens can now do so.

headline: Book Says Melania Trump Delayed Washington Move as Negotiating Tack
text: Melania Trump, the first lady, remained in New York during the first months of her husband’s presidency because she was renegotiating their prenuptial agreement after his surprise victory in the 2016 election, according to a new book.

headline: Trump Administration Erases Transgender Civil Rights Protections in Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday finalized a regulation that will erase protections for transgender patients against discrimination by doctors, hospitals and health insurance companies, a move announced on the four-year anniversary of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando and in the middle of Pride Month.

headline: 12 Streamable Plays That Depict Black Lives Pierced by Racism
text: Violence against black people is nothing new — not in real life and not in the theater. Especially in the last few years, playwrights have been telling the stories, sounding the alarm and predicting our current upheaval. Newer works, too, created under the stress of grief, have been trying to put George Floyd and Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor and too many others in a larger context.

headline: Remember the Election?
text: On Thursday’s episode, we spoke with Astead Herndon, a national political reporter, about the logistical meltdown in Georgia’s primary election. Astead was a regular guest on our series The Field, taking us with him on the campaign trail earlier this year. We asked him to reflect on what has changed since his last appearance for that show:

headline: For Much of Europe, Reopening Day Is Here
text: As the world slowly reopens to tourism, June 15 — and, in some cases, June 16 — has emerged as a significant date, especially in Europe, where the European Union plans on lifting many internal borders. Additional waves of reopenings are expected later in the summer, but for now, visitors from the United States aren’t typically on the invite list.

headline: ‘Tenet,’ Expected to Signal Hollywood’s Return, Is Pushed Back

headline: Amazon Said to Be Under Scrutiny in 2 States for Abuse of Power
text: SEATTLE — State investigators in California and Washington have been looking into whether Amazon abuses its power over sellers on the tech giant’s site, according to people involved with the inquiry.

headline: A Homecoming of Good Fortune for an Artist’s Pile of Cookies
text: It is a quiet homecoming: a mound of fortune cookies on a Havana rooftop overlooking a wide, green river. Art lovers come in ones and twos, cracking open a cookie to read their fortunes, sometimes popping the treat in their mouths.

headline: William S. Sessions, F.B.I. Director at a Turbulent Time, Dies at 90
text: William S. Sessions, a director of the F.B.I. under three presidents, from 1987 to 1993, who challenged racial and gender bias in his agency but struggled to redefine its mission in a time of domestic turmoil, and who was fired after being accused of ethical lapses, died on Friday in San Antonio. He was 90.

headline: Four Poachers Arrested After Killing of Rare Silverback Gorilla in Uganda
text: Four poachers were arrested this week in connection with the killing of a rare silverback gorilla in Uganda’s Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, a lush preserve of mist-shrouded hillsides and thick rain forests that is home to nearly half of the world’s mountain gorillas, the authorities said.

headline: N.Y. Bans Chokeholds and Approves Other Measures to Restrict Police
text: New York on Friday became one of the first states to take meaningful action to restrict police forces after the killing of George Floyd, banning the use of chokeholds by law enforcement and repealing a half-century-old law that has kept police disciplinary records secret in the state.

headline: Virus Exposes Weak Links in Peru’s Success Story

headline: Player Pushback Emerges as N.B.A. Works to Complete Restart Plans
text: The N.B.A. on Friday furnished teams with an expected timeline for the rest of the season but also notified them that it has not yet completed negotiations with the players’ union on the health and safety protocols that would govern the planned resumption of play at Walt Disney World Resort next month, according to a private memorandum obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Arizona Finds Coronavirus Among Border Wall Workers
text: Health officials in southern Arizona have detected at least two coronavirus cases among workers on the border wall, igniting fears that the influx of hundreds of construction workers could spread the virus in small border towns.

headline: Yes, We Mean Literally Abolish the Police
text: Congressional Democrats want to make it easier to identify and prosecute police misconduct; Joe Biden wants to give police departments $300 million. But efforts to solve police violence through liberal reforms like these have failed for nearly a century.

headline: New York Voters Can Send Some Promising New Faces to Congress
text: At a time when millions of voices are calling out for peaceful change, New Yorkers can make an immediate difference with this year’s primary elections. In-person voting begins June 13 and ends June 23; voting by absentee ballot has already begun. The nation badly needs new faces, new energy, new talent and new ideas.

headline: A Flag for All in Mississippi
text: OXFORD, Miss. — I’m a proud Mississippian, and our state’s poet laureate, but I don’t fly the state flag. Neither do my friends and neighbors, white or black (I’m white). The reason is simple: Mississippi, which has the country’s highest percentage of black residents, is the last state in the nation to have a flag that incorporates the Confederate symbol.

headline: I’m a Black American. I Had to Get Out.
text: LAMBEAU, Trinidad and Tobago — I watched the video of George Floyd taking his last breaths under the knee of a Minneapolis police officer while scrolling through Facebook early one morning here. The sound of crashing waves and my children’s giggles created the soundtrack for the devastating images.

headline: Two Years After Trump-Kim Meeting, Little to Show for Personal Diplomacy
text: The timing was hardly coincidental when North Korea’s foreign minister declared on Friday that hopes for finding peace with South Korea and its protector, the United States, “faded away into a dark nightmare,” and that talking with President Trump had given way to focusing on a more “reliable force to cope with the long-term military threats from the U.S.”

text: Asbury Park, N.J., is Murphy country.

headline: A New York Comedy Club Tries to Bring Back Stand-Up
text: For months, New York’s stand-up comedians have been deprived of what they love the most: taking the stage of a dingy comedy club, grabbing the microphone off the stand and staring out at a sea of people whose laughter has the power to determine their own self-worth.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: During the initial phase of the coronavirus pandemic, an apparent anomaly was puzzling health experts around the world: Why was the virus pummeling rich countries, but seemed to leave many poorer nations relatively untouched?

headline: Cynthia Navaretta, Who Promoted Female Artists, Is Dead at 97
text: Cynthia Navaretta, who with a newsletter, a publishing house and an unflagging enthusiasm promoted female artists for decades, beginning at a time when male domination of the art world was particularly pronounced, died on May 18 at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: After Two Rounds, Jordan Spieth Shows No Signs of Rust

headline: Pentagon Denies Spying on Americans Protesting Police Killings

headline: Calls for Transforming Police Run Into Realities of Governing in Minnesota
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The calls for sweeping reforms to policing that have reverberated since the death of George Floyd slammed into the messy realities of lawmaking on Friday, offering a glimpse of the uncertainties of turning protest into policy.

headline: Graduating West Point Cadets Isolate for Two Weeks Ahead of Trump Speech
text: WASHINGTON — The graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy at West Point have lived in Covid-19 quarantine for the past two weeks, confined to their dorms, wearing masks and watching Zoom conferences on leadership as they wait for President Trump to speak at their commencement on Saturday.

headline: Dave Chappelle’s Netflix Special: Three Key References to Know
text: Dave Chappelle released a lacerating new special, “8:46” — the length of time that a police officer held his knee on George Floyd’s neck as Floyd pleaded for his life — that has become among the first live shows in the Covid era to reckon with the protests gripping the nation.

headline: Trump Says He Opposes Police Chokeholds, Except in Certain Situations
text: President Trump appeared to support outlawing chokeholds as a law enforcement practice in an interview with Fox News that aired on Friday, but not before he defended their use in certain situations in a rambling response to a question about police reform efforts.

headline: Prime Minister Boris Johnson Stirs Culture War Over Churchill Statue

headline: Club Owners?
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There’s an expression that goes “when you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras.” If you’re doing a Trenton Charlson puzzle, think Quaggas; think lots of high scoring scrabble words, X’s, Q’s and Z’s in unexpected places. Mr. Charlson is more than a one-trick pony and today there are some good puns and factoids to explore.

headline: Celebrate Pride With Town Halls and Club Beats
text: If you’re feeling conflicted about how to celebrate Pride this year, you’re hardly alone. Three months after the coronavirus pandemic turned the world on its head, America has been rocked by coast-to-coast protests inspired by George Floyd, whose death has led millions to cry out for an end to police brutality — and an end to police departments generally.

headline: Roger Cohen: The Outcry Over ‘Both Sides’ Journalism
text: The acting editorial page editor, Kathleen Kingsbury, wrote about the decision to publish our writers’ responses to the Tom Cotton Op-Ed in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: Latest Crop of West Point Graduates Includes First Observant Sikh Cadet
text: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the stage on Saturday to deliver the commencement speech at West Point, one of the new Army officers he addressed was an Indian-American woman breaking a barrier as old as the 218-year-old military academy.

headline: Corrections: June 13, 2020
text: An article on Friday about the renewed scrutiny of European police that has followed the demonstrations against police brutality in the United States misstated the given name of the Human Rights Watch director in France. She is Bénédicte Jeannerod, not Béatrice.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Houses of Prayer, Hope and Testing for Most Affected

headline: So You Want to Learn About Juneteenth?
text: Juneteenth, an annual holiday commemorating the end of slavery in the United States, has been celebrated by African-Americans since the late 1800s.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Split’ and a ‘Dateline’ Special
text: THE SPLIT Stream on Sundance Now, Sundance TV, Amazon, Google Play, Hulu, iTunes and YouTube TV. On the first season of this drama, centered around a family of high-powered divorce lawyers, Ruth Defoe (Deborah Findlay), the matriarch, gives a speech at her daughter’s wedding that gets at the heart of the series. “I have found through life that love and hate are so often intertwined,” she says. “Or perhaps, I should say, that the love that’s there at the start is still there at the end.” As Ruth and her daughters Nina (Annabel Scholey) and Hannah (Nicola Walker), both lawyers, help their clients navigate the often heartless legal world of infidelity, prenuptial agreements and divorce, they are forced to come to terms with the emotional challenges in their own relationships. As Margaret Lyons, a television critic for The New York Times, wrote in her Watching column: “If you like ensemble dramas in which smart, elegant people stand in nice kitchens and sadly ponder their lives, watch this.”

headline: The Teachings of the Philosopher of the Black Forest
text: Christian Streich has to go. He is conscious that it is nearing 10 a.m., and training is about to start. His S.C. Freiburg players — he calls them his “colleagues” — will soon be out on the field, wondering where their coach has gone. With a hint of apology, he wonders if we might, perhaps, make these the last couple of questions?

headline: Bubba Wallace Thankful for Flag Ban, but NASCAR’s Fans Might Not Be
text: Now that Darrell Wallace Jr., the sole African-American driver in NASCAR’s top racing series, has persuaded the organization to bar the Confederate flag from its events, he expects his life to be a little different.

headline: How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America
text: George Floyd’s death has sparked more than two weeks of protests in all 50 states. See how the movement spread.

headline: 8 Are Shot in San Antonio by Man Claiming to Be U.F.C. Fighter
text: Eight people were shot late Friday in a San Antonio parking lot by a man who, after being turned away from a bar, came back and opened fire with a rifle, the police said.

headline: Making Stories of Struggle a Thing of the Past
text: We come from different worlds, my wife and I, but we both call America home.

headline: Trump Has Made Alternative Facts a Way of Life
text: No president in the history of our Republic has been as disorienting as Donald Trump. His goal, even before he became president, was far more ambitious than to tell mere lies. It was to annihilate the distinction between truth and falsity, to make sure that we no longer share facts in common, to overwhelm people with misinformation and disinformation. It was to induce epistemological vertigo on a mass scale.

headline: When a Cemetery Wedding Was Used to End the Spanish Flu
text: Even as New York reopens ever so cautiously, couples hoping to stage big, boisterous weddings in the city still have a good wait ahead of them before they receive a go-ahead.

headline: Finally, a Wedding. It Was About Time.
text: When I was 6, I had an imaginary husband I named Dave the Watchmaker. We had a wedding ceremony in the living room where my grandma sat as the lone guest while my mother played the organ. I carried a giant baby doll with me down the aisle to meet Dave.

headline: How a New Yorker Cartoonist Spends Her Sundays
text: Liana Finck’s cartoons have wobbly lines, potato-headed characters with names like “blunt person,” and a deeply sympathetic contemporary anguish. “The most relatable thing,” Ms. Finck said, “is to show the thought in its original, messy form.”

headline: Vet Your Social Media
text: With the combination of camera phones and social media, more people than ever are being made aware of incidents of police brutality and racial inequality, and of the protests they have touched off.But making sense of the deluge of posts in the present moment can be difficult.

headline: How to Get Your Kids to Stay 6 Feet Away… From Everything
text: It’s hard enough for adults to maintain social distancing — you’ve seen those photos of crowded beaches and parks — but for young children? That’s a whole other challenge. Here are some tips for getting your kids (especially those under 5) to care about wearing masks and steering six feet away from strangers.

headline: Faced With Crisis and Re-election, Senate Republicans Blame China
text: WASHINGTON — When Senator Martha McSally, one of the most politically endangered Republicans, was asked last month about reports that President Trump had brushed away warnings from his own aides about the looming threat of the coronavirus, she promptly pivoted.
